Step 0 / 12 Introduction
The brute force approach copies the list in two passes. First, create all nodes with next pointers. Then, for each random pointer, find its position by traversing the original list, then traverse the copy to set the pointer. Click "Next" to begin!
‚ö†Ô∏è Why is this O(n¬≤)?
For each of n nodes, we traverse up to n nodes to find the random target's position, then traverse up to n more nodes in the copy. That's n √ó (n + n) = O(n¬≤) operations!
Ready to start
brute-force.js
function copyRandomList(head) {
if (!head) return null;
// Pass 1: Create nodes with next pointers
let copyHead = new Node(head.val);
let origCurr = head.next, copyCurr = copyHead;
while (origCurr) {
copyCurr.next = new Node(origCurr.val);
copyCurr = copyCurr.next;
origCurr = origCurr.next;
}
// Pass 2: Set random pointers using position
origCurr = head; copyCurr = copyHead;
while (origCurr) {
if (origCurr.random) {
let pos = findPosition(head, origCurr.random);
copyCurr.random = getNodeAt(copyHead, pos);
}
origCurr = origCurr.next;
copyCurr = copyCurr.next;
}
return copyHead;
}
